sub_topic: Calculation of magnetic field due to a current-carrying plane
message_1: A rectangular loop of wire has a length of 20 cm and a width of 10 cm. The loop carries a current of 2 A. Determine the magnetic field strength at a point 5 cm away from the plane of the loop.
message_2:
To determine the magnetic field strength at a point 5 cm away from the plane of the loop, we can use the formula for the magnetic field produced by a rectangular loop:

B = (μ₀ * I * a * b) / (4 * π * (a^2 + x^2)^(3/2))

where B is the magnetic field strength, μ₀ is the permeability of free space (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A), I is the current, a and b are the dimensions of the loop (length and width), and x is the distance from the plane of the loop.

Given the values:
I = 2 A
a = 20 cm = 0.2 m
b = 10 cm = 0.1 m
x = 5 cm = 0.05 m

Plugging these values into the formula:

B = (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A * 2 A * 0.2 m * 0.1 m) / (4 * π * (0.2^2 + 0.05^2)^(3/2))

B = (8π × 10^(-7) Tm * 0.02 m^2) / (4 * π * (0.04 + 0.0025)^(3/2))

B = (1.6 × 10^(-7) Tm) / ((0.0425)^(3/2))

B ≈ 1.6 × 10^(-7) Tm / 0.0103

B ≈ 1.55 × 10^(-5) T

The magnetic field strength at a point 5 cm away from the plane of the loop is approximately 1.55 × 10^(-5) T (Tesla).
